title: Asda defends decision to refuse to serve mum-of-five six minutes before supermarket closed
text:

Asda bosses have defended a decision not to allow a mum-of-five into their supermarket six minutes before trading ceased. 
Antonia Simons called at the store in Scunthorpe, North East Lincs, at 3.54pm on Sunday, February 26 to buy a replacement duvet. 
But she was stopped at the entrance by a security guard who pointed out the store closed at 4pm and she would not have time to make her purchase. 
Ms Simons, who works for rivals Tesco, told the Scunthorpe Telegraph: "I pointed out there was still six minutes to go and I had time to get the duvet and pay for it at the tills before they closed – but he still refusd me entry. 
"A lot of shoppers paying at the tills overheard the exchange and urged the guard to let me in. Some others even offered to purchase the duvet for me. 
"There was no notice displayed indicating the latest time you can enter the store on a Sunday." 
She said another shopper, who wanted gravy salts, was also turned away at the same time. Read More Giant Kinder eggs are finally here – here's where to get them 
An Asda spokesman said: "In line with trading law, our stores are open for six hours on Sundays. 
"The opening and closing hours may vary from store to store, but I'm sure most people will recognise that we must operate within the legal limits and close at the end of the six hour period. 
"Our stores are open for six hours on a Sunday and trading laws require we close promptly. 
"We always want to serve our customers, but on this occasion time just wasn't on our side. 
"We've spoken to Ms Simons to resolve the issue and look forward to welcoming her in store again soon." Like us on Facebook
